channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Robert Slater, Journalist and Author, Dies at 70
item.description: Mr. Slater covered Israel for Time for two tumultuous decades and wrote more than two dozen books.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY

item.title: China Extends Tax Break Program to Spur Economy
item.description: China’s cabinet decided to continue the breaks for small and very small enterprises through 2016 and said it was considering significantly broadening them.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Syria Accuses Rebels of Planning Gas Attack
item.description: In a letter to the United Nations, Syria said that opposition groups were planning a toxic gas attack in a rebel-held area near Damascus so they could blame it on government forces.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: A part of Aleppo, Syria, that activists said was hit Wednesday by a government airstrike. Syria is charging in a letter to the United Nations that opposition groups are planning a toxic gas attack near Damascus so they can then blame the government for it.

item.title: DealBook: A Muddy Tract Now, but by 2020, China’s Answer to Wall St.
item.description: A largely empty expanse in Shenzhen is the setting for a financial experiment that could have a huge impact on the world’s second-largest economy. But so far it is just a bold blueprint.
item.category: Bank of New York Mellon Corporation|BK|NYSE
Bank of New York Mellon Corporation
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: The Qianhai special economic zone in Shenzhen

item.title: Deposed Ukrainian Leader Calls Crimea Annexation a ‘Tragedy’
item.description: In a tearful interview from Russia, Viktor F. Yanukovych said he would try to negotiate the region’s return from President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: World Briefing: Japan Says It Will Abide by Whaling Ruling
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said Wednesday that he would comply with an international court order to halt Japanese whale hunts off Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: World Briefing: Ex-C.I.A. Official Defends Actions After Benghazi Strike
item.description: The former deputy director of the C.I.A. said he was not pressured to edit the widely debunked talking points on the 2012 Benghazi attack in an effort to protect President Obama and former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Musharraf Barred From Traveling Abroad
item.description: The Interior Ministry has rejected a request from former President Pervez Musharraf to go abroad for what he contends is a chance to seek medical treatment and to see his ailing mother.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: 24 Suspected of Secessionist Plot Are Arrested
item.description: Special operations forces arrested 24 people Wednesday who were suspected of planning a violent independence campaign for the wealthy northeastern Veneto region.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: Foreign Ministry Strike Ends
item.description: Employees of the ministry on Wednesday announced the end of an unprecedented strike over pay and working conditions that had shut the offices and 103 missions abroad for over a week.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: World Briefing: Greece: Immunity Lifted for Lawmakers
item.description: Greece’s Parliament on Wednesday voted to lift the immunity of another four of the Golden Dawn party’s lawmakers so they can face trial on charges of setting up a criminal organization.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: In Bullet-Ridden Afghan Districts, Free Vote Seems an Empty Promise
item.description: As the body count for Afghan security forces has risen, it has become clear that no one is going to vote on Saturday in embattled districts like Charkh.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Soldiers at an Afghan Army command center for election operations in Charkh District. Officials say it is unlikely anyone there will come out to vote on Saturday.

item.title: In Afghanistan, a Campaign of Resilience
item.description: Barring last-minute catastrophe, Afghans will vote on Saturday with a turnout that the United Nations hopes will reach 50 percent.
item.dc:creator: By BRYAN DENTON

item.title: NASA Breaks Most Contact With Russia
item.description: The space agency suspended contact except over operations of the International Space Station, underscoring the rapid deterioration of ties in the wake of the Kremlin’s annexation of Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By KENNETH CHANG and PETER BAKER

item.title: Hope for Negotiations Stays Alive in Mideast
item.description: Even as the Palestinian leadership took formal steps on Wednesday to gain the benefits of statehood outside the negotiation process, the parties appeared ready to seek a formula for continuing the negotiations.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN, ISABEL KERSHNER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Relatives of victims who were killed in Palestinian attacks gathered on Wednesday in Jerusalem.

item.title: Responding to Quake, Chile Uses Lessons of Past
item.description: Compared with the reaction to a 2010 disaster, the response by Chilean officials to a magnitude-8.2 earthquake Tuesday revealed important shifts in emergency preparation.
item.dc:creator: By PASCALE BONNEFOY and SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Firefighters in Iquique, Chile, battled a blaze that started after Tuesday’s 8.2-magnitude earthquake, which left six people dead, according to the authorities.

item.title: Memo From Afghanistan: War and Unrest Provide for a Scarred Campaign Trail in Afghanistan
item.description: Amid repeated Taliban attacks and a continuing war, Afghan presidential candidates step onto planes with guards carrying AK-47s, and rocket-propelled grenades are sometimes part of carry-on baggage.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and AZAM AHMED

item.title: National Briefing | Washington: Ex-Contractor Sentenced for Leak to Fox News
item.description: A federal judge on Wednesday sentenced a former State Department contractor to 13 months in prison for leaking information about North Korea to a Fox News reporter.
item.dc:creator: By

item.title: Iran’s Choice for U.N. Post Fuels Tension With U.S.
item.description: Washington has yet to announce a decision on a visa for Hamid Aboutalebi, a diplomat with links to the group behind the 1979 hostage crisis in Tehran.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Lens Blog: Finding Chris Hondros
item.description: Chris Hondros’s “Testament” captures the mind and eye of a photographer who was killed in war. But to those who knew him, it is a chance to continue conversations started long ago.
item.dc:creator: By TODD HEISLER
item.media:description: Two children with United States soldiers after their parents were killed. Their car was fired on by American troops after it failed to stop and went toward soldiers, despite warning shots, during a dusk patrol. Jan. 18, 2005. Tal Afar, Iraq.

item.title: Cairo University Is Rocked by Several Explosions
item.description: Blasts in the Egyptian capital killed at least one police officer and wounded several others in the first major attack since the start of the presidential campaign.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: A man helped a victim of the bombings in Cairo on Wednesday. The attacks threatened to deepen the turmoil on campuses in Egypt.

item.title: For Many Germans, Pilots’ Walkout Crosses a Line
item.description: A three-day work stoppage by Lufthansa pilots appears to be breaking the unwritten rules of German workplace relations.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: Lufthansa pilots are on a three-day strike, forcing the global airline to cancel about 3,800 flights.

item.title: The Lede: Reaction to the Supreme Court’s Campaign Finance Decision
item.description: The Supreme Court decision struck down limits on federal campaign contributions. It only concerned those from individuals. Federal law continues to ban contributions by corporations and unions.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: French Leader Approves a Cabinet of Mixed Messages
item.description: With some of his appointments, President François Hollande appeared to be trying to satisfy leftist factions in his Socialist Party, but he seemed no closer to a coherent economic policy.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: Ségolène Royal, the newly named environment and energy minister, arrived on Wednesday at a ministry building in Paris.

item.title: Yanukovych Says He Was ‘Wrong’ on Crimea
item.description: Ukraine’s ousted president said that he was “wrong” to have invited Russian troops into Crimea and vowed to try to persuade Russia to return the coveted Black Sea peninsula.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
